items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message:
Flooding is possible today, Saturday 25 October, and tomorrow, Sunday 26th October.

Tide locking where high tides restrict normal drainage of the river out to sea,  over the next two days may lead to flooding. 

We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.  River levels will remain high over the next couple of days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 10:00am tomorrow, Sunday 26 October 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rye catchment
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: Tide locking where high tides restrict normal drainage of the river out to sea, over the next two days may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible today, Saturday 25th October 2025, and tomorrow. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. River levels will remain high over the next couple of days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00am tomorrow, Sunday 26th October 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message:
Flooding is possible today, Saturday 25 October, and tomorrow Sunday 26 October.
Tide locking where high tides restrict normal drainage of the river out to sea,  over the next two days may lead to flooding.
We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. River levels will remain high over the next couple of days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10:00am tomorrow, Sunday 26 October 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 10:45pm to 1:30am BST (9:45pm to 12:30am GMT) tonight and from 08:30am to 12:45pm on 26 October 
We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Lowestoft of 1.71mAODN at 12:30am BST (11.30pm GMT), tonight, Saturday 25th October 2025, which is 0.97m above tide tables, Wind Force 7, North Westerly. The forecast for the following tide is for a peak level of 1.80mAODN at 11:15am GMT, tomorrow, Sunday 26th October 2025, which is 0.80m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, North Westerly. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 26 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 2:30am to 3:30am BST (1:30am to 2:30am GMT) overnight, in the early hours of Sunday 26 October. 
Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Harwich of 2.63mAODN at 2:45am BST (1:45am GMT), overnight, in the early hours of Sunday 26th October 2025, which is 0.77m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, Westerly. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 26 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message:
High tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 6:30AM to 11:00AM on 26/10/25. 
Locations most affected will be coastal roads and footpaths along the North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including Sandsend and tidal River Esk. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 26 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message:
High tides overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 2:30am to 3:30am BST (1:30am to 2:30am GMT) overnight in the early hours of Sunday, 26 October. 
The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded.  Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Harwich of 2.63mAODN at 2:45am BST (1:45am GMT), overnight, in the early hours of Sunday 26th October 2025, which is 0.77m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, Westerly. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 26 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
If you have been evacuated only return to your property once the emergency services have advised that it is safe to do so. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: High tides, strong winds and large waves this evening may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible from 7:00PM to 10:30PM on 25/10/25. Locations most affected will be coastal roads and footpaths along the North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded. Also avoid beaches and coastal promenades, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 26th October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions over the next two days may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible 19:00 to 23:00 on 25.10.2025 and from 06:00 to 10:00am on 26.10.2025. 
Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront.  Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  King's Lynn of 3.61mAODN at  21:00 on Saturday  25th which is 0.51m above tide tables, wind force 6, north westerly. The following tide on Sunday morning will peak at 3.32mAOD at 08:00am wind force 6, north westerly. Tides will remain high over the next couple of days. 
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities . 
Avoid beaches and coastal promenades, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 12:00AM on 26 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
The previous tide of concern has now passed,  the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: The Suffolk coast from Lowestoft to Bawdsey
items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 10:45pm to 1:30am BST (9:45pm to 12:30am GMT) tonight and from 08:30am to 12:45pm on 26 October 
We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft as well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.71mAODN at 12:30am BST (11.30pm GMT), tonight, 25/10/2025, which is 0.97m above tide tables, Wind Force 7, North Westerly. The forecast for the following tide is for a peak level of 1.80mAODN at 11:15am GMT, on 26/10/2025, which is 0.80m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, North Westerly. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 26 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isolated low lying properties along the tidal River Waveney
items.message:
Tide locking, where high tides restrict normal drainage of the river out to sea, is expected to cause flooding overnight.  
Flooding is expected from 1:30am to 3:00am BST (12:30am to 2:00am GMT) tonight and 10:30am to 2:45pm on 26 October.  
Areas most at risk are in St Olaves, Somerleyton, Burgh St Peter, Oulton Broad and Beccles. Roads likely to be affected include Beccles Road at St Olaves, Geldeston Lock Lane, Gillingham Dam and Fen Lane in Beccles. River levels will remain high over the next couple of days.  
We are closely monitoring the situation .  
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded .  
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 26 October 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Riverside properties along the tidal River Yare including Cantley, Brundall and Reedham
items.message:
Tide locking, where high tides restrict normal drainage of the river out to sea, is expected to cause flooding overnight. 
Flooding is expected from 1:00am to 4:00am BST (12:00am to 3:00am GMT) tonight and 10:30am to 4:00pm on 26 October.   
Areas most at risk are in Reedham, Cantley and Brundall. Roads affected include Ferry Road in Reedham, the A47 and the railway line between Reedham and Brundall. River levels will remain high over the next couple of days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 26 October 2025 or as the situation changes.
